Key Arguments: The legislation will erode democracy and is selectively applied, excluding certain groups and the government.
The author opposes censorship by Big Tech, governments, and bureaucrats, advocating for the ability to access independent media and form personal opinions.
The mainstream media and government are unreliable for providing independent information, as demonstrated by the COVID-19 pandemic and the 'No' campaign for the proposed voice to parliament.
The term 'hate speech' is used to silence dissenting opinions.
There is a risk of re-categorizing information sources that the government disagrees with, leading to censorship.
Governments and corporations should not be arbiters of truth; information should be debated openly.
Main Themes: Distrust in government and mainstream media
Concerns about selective application of laws
Opposition to government and corporate control over information
Notable Quotes: This bill will erode democracy in all its forms, and is particularly sinister because it wonâ€™t apply to certain groups and the government.
I am perfectly capable of reading widely, researching and forming my own opinion.
Governments, Big Tech and unelected bureaucrats should never have the right to be arbiters of truth.
Take your proposed Communications Legislation Amendment (Combating Misinformation and Disinformation) Bill 2023 bill and throw it off the nearest cliff.
